Jim - 

You may have seen these in Tampa but here is a link showing the menuki that I was asking about: 
http://www.nihonto.com/11.3.07.html

Papered as Kyo-kinko, maybe these fall into that area as you mentioned where it is difficult to "date" them or to assign a maker. Can you comment on these that I purchased? Work seems very nice to my eye and I'm certainly happy with them.

Ron
STL

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 5:36 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko


  Kyo-kinko is non-Goto (non-Mino, etc.) kinko work from after the Momoyama period. It is often applied to work that is in Goto style but is not Goto main or sideline work. Edo-kinko used to be used similarly for work in the style of Edo region machibori kinko schools, but lately this is generally lumped as "Kyo-kinko" as well. So it truly is a grab bag, but the problem (especially with menuki) is that there is so much Edo period kinko work with no unique character to it that makes it possible to give a more specific attribution.

  BTW, generic Edo period kinko work of lower quality than Kyo-kinko is attributed to Kyo-kanagushi.

  Jim

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: ROBSON Gordon 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, February 27, 2008 4:23 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kyo-kinko

  Hi Ron,

  My understanding is that Kyo-Kinko is the new name for Waki-Goto. This would 
  make them a grab bag like Ko-Kinko or even Shoami. Their dates are post-Ko-
  Kinko, so early Edo to Bakumatsu. There is a Kyo-Kinko book out there. I think the 
  title is Kyo-Kinko no Kenkyu (research into Kyo-Kinko) or something like that. Jim 
  is probably better up on this stuff then I am.

  On on different note, good luck to Harry. Honto ni gambatte kudasai!!

  Gordon
